title: Bob Livingston thrust back in impeachment glare after grabbing headlines in Clinton era
text:
“He characterized Ambassador Yovanovitch as an ‘Obama holdover’ and associated with George Soros,” Croft said in her opening statement. “It was not clear to me at the time — or now — at whose direction or at whose expense Mr. Livingston was seeking the removal of Ambassador Yovanovitch.”

Livingston’s lobbying disclosure filings shed little light on who — if anyone — paid Livingston to push for Yovanovitch’s ouster. Her removal has become a focus of investigators examining Ukraine shadow diplomacy carried out by President Donald Trump’s personal attorney Rudy Giuliani and his associates. Trump ultimately recalled Yovanovitch in May.

But the filings do show that Livingston and his firm, the Livingston Group, represented multiple Ukraine-related clients during Trump’s presidency. And Croft’s testimony has thrust the former congressman into the spotlight of the impeachment inquiry, as House Democrats more broadly examine Trump’s attempts to pressure Ukraine to investigate his political rivals.

Livingston didn’t respond to a request for comment on Wednesday.

It’s unclear when Livingston’s conversations with Croft about Yovanovitch took place. But a Justice Department disclosure filed by his firm shows that Livingston spoke with Croft and another White House aide, Virginia Boney, by phone on May 17, 2018, as part of his lobbying work for a Ukrainian association of steel companies. They discussed Trump’s steel tariffs and the upcoming visit to Washington of Natalia Mykolska, Ukraine’s deputy minister of economic development and trade.

Livingston worked for the trade group, called the Association of Enterprises UKRMETALURGPROM, for only two months. He and other staffers at his firm called and emailed administration officials and members of Congress about the tariffs and Mykolska’s trip to Washington but didn’t accompany her to meetings once she arrived.

Livingston’s firm was paid $40,000 — a modest fee in the lucrative realm of foreign lobbying.

Livingston made far more money lobbying for another Ukrainian client, Innovative Technology and Business Consulting LLC, which hired his firm last year shortly before he stopped working for the steel trade group in early July. The limited-liability company, which reported an address in suburban Baltimore, paid Livingston’s firm more than $450,000, according to disclosure filings.

Livingston lobbied on behalf of “concerned citizens of Ukraine” who supported Yulia Tymoshenko, a former Ukrainian prime minister running to be the country’s president, according to a disclosure filing. When Tymoshenko lost the presidential race earlier this year, Livingston’s firm talked her up as a potential prime minister.

Livingston and others accompanied Tymoshenko in December to meetings in Washington with members of Congress and administration officials, including Kurt Volker, Trump’s special representative for Ukraine negotiations at the time. Former Rep. Bob McEwen (R-Ohio), who was working with Livingston, introduced Tymoshenko to Giuliani, who has urged Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden.

McEwen didn’t respond to a request for comment.

It’s unclear whether either of Livingston’s Ukrainian clients had any reason to want to oust Yovanovitch.

Livingston’s firm isn’t one of the largest on K Street, but it represents several well-known clients, including the software giants Oracle and Adobe and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, according to disclosure filings. Livingston has also lobbied in recent years for the governments of Iraq and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

Livingston has defended his work, writing in a memoir published last year that he’d “made a lot of money” after leaving Congress, “only to narrowly avoid bankruptcy in recent years.”

In the book, titled “The Windmill Chaser: Triumphs and Less in American Politics,” Livingston wrote, “For those who view the word ‘lobby’ as a four-letter word, I’ll simply say everyone has the Constitutional right to petition his or her elected representatives.”
